title: Pain Tracking
milkProductionTips: Tips to Increase Breast Milk Production
frequentFeedingDescription: Frequent feeding stimulates more milk production.
stayHydratedDescription: Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated.
balancedDietDescription: Eat a nutritious and balanced diet to support milk production.
restAndStressManagementDescription: Get enough rest and manage stress to ensure good milk flow.
useBreastPumpDescription: Regular pumping can help increase milk supply.
checkLatchDescription: Ensure your baby has a good latch to effectively extract milk.
avoidSupplementsDescription: Do not use supplements without consulting your doctor.
naturalGalactagoguesDescription: Certain foods and herbs can naturally boost milk production.

follow_detailed_instructions: Follow these detailed instructions for proper breastfeeding.
no_steps_available: No steps available at the moment.
explanatory_videos_item: Watch explanatory videos on breastfeeding techniques
audio_guide_item: Listen to audio instructions for each step
step1_description: Find a comfortable position and ensure you have everything you need nearby.
step2_description: Hold your baby close, supporting their head and neck.
step3_description: Guide your nipple to your baby's mouth, ensuring a deep latch.
step4_description: Look for signs of proper feeding, such as rhythmic sucking and swallowing.
step5_description: Gently break the suction and remove your baby from the breast when finished.
bestPositionForBreastfeeding:
The best position for breastfeeding is the one where both you and your baby are comfortable. Common positions include:
• Cradle hold
• Cross-cradle hold
• Football hold
• Side-lying position
Ensure a good latch and that the baby's head and body are aligned.
signsBabyIsGettingEnoughMilk:
Signs your baby is getting enough milk include:
• Regular wet and dirty diapers
• Steady weight gain
• Content after feedings
• Proper latch and swallowing sounds
Monitor feeding cues and consult a healthcare provider if concerned.
breastfeedingAfterVaccination:
Yes, you can breastfeed after vaccination. Benefits include:
• Comforting your baby
• Potentially reducing mild side effects
• Providing immune-boosting antibodies
breastfeedingTips:
Tips for successful breastfeeding:
1. Ensure a good latch
2. Feed on demand
3. Stay hydrated
4. Eat a balanced diet
5. Seek support when needed
6. Be patient with yourself and your baby
breastfeedingPain:
While initial discomfort is normal, ongoing pain isn't. Possible causes:
• Improper latch
• Engorgement
• Mastitis
Consult a lactation consultant or healthcare provider if pain persists.
increaseMilkSupply:
To increase milk supply:
• Feed more frequently
• Ensure proper latch
• Use both breasts per feeding
• Pump after feedings
• Stay hydrated and well-nourished
• Manage stress
Consult a lactation specialist for personalized advice.
medicationWhileBreastfeeding: Many medications are safe while breastfeeding, but always consult your healthcare provider before starting any new medication. Some can pass into breast milk and may affect your baby.
breastfeedingInPublic:
Tips for public breastfeeding:
• Wear accessible clothing
• Use a nursing cover if desired
• Find a comfortable spot
• Practice at home
• Know your rights
Remember, breastfeeding is natural and protected in many places.
breastfeedingDuration:
WHO recommends:
• Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months
• Continued breastfeeding with complementary foods up to 2 years or beyond
Duration is a personal decision based on individual circumstances.
dietWhileBreastfeeding:
A balanced breastfeeding diet includes:
• Variety of fruits and vegetables
• Whole grains
• Lean proteins
• Healthy fats
Stay hydrated and limit caffeine and alcohol. Monitor your baby for food sensitivities.
breastfeedingWithIllness:
You can breastfeed with a cold or flu. Precautions:
• Wash hands frequently
• Avoid coughing/sneezing near baby
• Consider wearing a mask
Breast milk provides protective antibodies to your baby.
